body: What version do you have? There was a patch release to fix this a couple months ago.
I'm using `reqwest v0.12.12`.

I'm trying the different versions:
- 0.12.9: works
- 0.12.10: error
- 0.12.11: error
- 0.12.12: error

The features used:
```
reqwest = { version = "=0.12.12", default-features = false, features = [
    "zstd",
    "rustls-tls",
] }
```

issue.title: "error decoding response body" after upgrading to 0.12.10

repository.name: reqwest
repository.description: An easy and powerful Rust HTTP Client

issue.body:
https://github.com/cargo-bins/cargo-binstall/actions/runs/12511426634/job/34903489849#step:5:1

```
ERROR Fatal error:

  × For crate b3sum: Reqwest error: error decoding response body
  ├─▶ Reqwest error: error decoding response body
  ├─▶ error decoding response body
  ╰─▶ there are extra bytes after body has been decompressed
```

body: Interesting. What if you use the default-tls instead of rustls? (The difference there is non-obvious, it likely changes whether HTTP/1.1 or 2 is used, because rustls supports ALPN.) Still though, that was the cause of the _previous_ issue. There must be some _other_ case where extra data bytes are received...

> Interesting. What if you use the default-tls instead of rustls?

I've already tried that, with the same result.

As I'm using `default-features = false`, http2 is deactivated no?
Oh, yes indeed.

I don't know if it makes sense what I'm thinking, but because the issue happens only for large payload:
Could it be an issue in the implementation of zstd, not handling well when the data is coming in multiple frames?
The same data in gzip encoding does not have this issue.

Unless the data is tiny (less than 8kb-ish), it's likely coming over in many "frames" (in HTTP/1.1, that's just read() calls on the socket).

If you can turn on `connection_verbose()`, and a logger, you'll see all the bytes the connection receives.

I could do this yes. I see the different reads.
After the panic:

   

Do you have an idea on how we can move forward on this issue.
Is there anything I can check?
You could look at the logs and determine what the connection is sending back, and why reqwest thinks there's more data _after_ the zstd decoder said it had finished.

Anything to check in particular?
As I wrote in one of the previous comment, there are quite a lot of extra bytes. I don't know what else I can check.

Is there a way to check if the issue is in the zstd decoder?

Just writing the data I'm finding:

- reqwest 0.12.9 with async-compression v0.4.20 works
- reqwest 0.12.12 with async-compression v0.4.20 does not work

changes between 0.12.9 and 0.12.10: https://github.com/seanmonstar/reqwest/compare/v0.12.9...v0.12.10

`git bisect` shows that this commit is where the behaviour broke, introduced by https://github.com/seanmonstar/reqwest/pull/2484:
```
d36c0f5fd93f8190c9f39990ce4ec859c2b6d567 is the first bad commit
commit d36c0f5fd93f8190c9f39990ce4ec859c2b6d567
Author: Andrey36652 <35865938+Andrey36652@users.noreply.github.com>
Date:   Tue Dec 3 19:01:58 2024 +0300

    perf: fix decoder streams to make pooled connections reusable (#2484)
    
    When a response body is being decompressed, and the length wasn't known, but was using chunked transfer-encoding, the remaining `0\r\n\r\n` was not consumed. That would leave the connection in a state that could be not be reused, and so the pool had to discard it.
    
    This fix makes sure the remaining end chunk is consumed, improving the amount of pooled connections that can be reused.
    
    Closes #2381 
```

issue.title: Poll inner connection until EOF after gzip decoder is complete

repository.name: reqwest
repository.description: An easy and powerful Rust HTTP Client

issue.title: add zstd test

repository.name: reqwest
repository.description: An easy and powerful Rust HTTP Client

issue.body: I was adding some tests to try to reproduce https://github.com/seanmonstar/reqwest/issues/2574, but no luck so far.

repository.name: reqwest
repository.description: An easy and powerful Rust HTTP Client

body: Some discussion happening here: https://github.com/seanmonstar/reqwest/pull/2484#issuecomment-2700831164

I notice that in async-compression, the `ZstdDecoder` has an option for `multiple_members(bool)`. I imagine setting that would fix this. My question is, is that the right place to do this? Is it expected in zstd to have multiple members? I believe in other algorithms that's supported but atypical. If you want to investigate _that_, it'd be good to have a solid answer before we blindly flip that switch.

If I [try this option](https://github.com/seanmonstar/reqwest/pull/2582/commits/93d64b02e78bd7e37e1695c671ccef7b9f4a1f69), this fixes the issue I'm having.
But the test https://github.com/seanmonstar/reqwest/pull/2582/commits/ab0f9fff7961109b953131896eac29400e0462d7 never completes.

> But the test [ab0f9ff](https://github.com/seanmonstar/reqwest/commit/ab0f9fff7961109b953131896eac29400e0462d7) never completes.

Because your ZSTD encoded data (in the test) is not full

issue.title: Support HTTP responses containing multiple ZSTD frames

repository.description: An easy and powerful Rust HTTP Client

body: @yanns https://github.com/seanmonstar/reqwest/pull/2583
don't think this issue is because of zstd. I am having exact same problem with same behavior using gzip
